metadata.case_name: M/s. Alopi Parshad and Sons Ltd. v. Union of India

facts.text: On May 3, 1937, M/s. Alopi Parshad and Sons Ltd. (Agents) appointed by Governor-General in Council as agents for purchasing ghee for Army from October 1, 1937, under written agreement.

Agreement clauses: Govt to pay actual expenses, financing/overhead mandi charges at Re. 1-1-0 per 100 lbs accepted ghee (cl.13), establishment/contingencies at annas 14 pies 6 per 100 lbs (cl.14), buying remuneration Re.1 per 100 lbs.
Agents undertake to provide working capital, bear costs including financing/overhead in buying markets (cl.13), bear establishment/contingency charges (cl.14).
Agents supplied ghee as required pursuant to agreement.
September 1939, World War II broke out, enormous increase in demand for ghee.
June 20, 1942, original agreement revised by mutual consent: graded scales for establishment/contingencies and remuneration effective from September 11, 1940.
December 6, 1943, Agents demanded enhancement: 25% increase buying remuneration, 20% establishment/contingencies, 112% mandi/financing charges due to war conditions.
Agents continued supplying till May 1945, no immediate reply from Govt.
May 17, 1945, Govt served notice of termination under cl.9.
May 22, 1945, Chief Director of Purchases replied to 1943 letter: no revision during currency, but ex-gratia for actual loss if justified; called for auditors' report.
Notice waived mutually; May 16, 1946 arrangement: Agents to supply 5000 tons by Oct 31, 1946, end of agreement.
July 1, 1946, Agents claimed dispute, appointed Nigam as arbitrator under cl.20, called on Govt to appoint.
July 10, 1946, Govt appointed Rangi Lal as arbitrator.
Before arbitrators, Agents claimed: Sch.A Rs.23,08,372 (original rates); alt Sch.B Rs.6,91,600 revised est/cont; Sch.C Rs.14,47,204 mandi; Sch.D Rs.2,41,235 damages termination.
Arbitrators disagreed, referred to umpire Lala Achru Ram.
Umpire: 1942 agreement valid, Sch.A untenable; Sch.B/C not arising from agreement, no jurisdiction; Sch.D outside reference.
Award filed in Subordinate Judge Delhi; Agents applied to set aside for misconduct (no opportunity, erred on jurisdiction).
Sub Judge: Umpire erred on Sch.B/D within reference, Sch.C outside; misconduct; set aside award, no supersede, parties appoint new under cl.20.
Union appealed to Punjab HC; Khosla J confirmed, misconduct, Sch.B/C not beyond agreement.
Letters Patent Appeal 31/1953 dismissed by Div Bench: Sch.B arises from contract, unnecessary on Sch.C.
Aug 9, 1952, Agents called for new arbitrator, reappointed Nigam.
Aug 14, 1952, Govt: appeal pending, but without prejudice reappointed Rangi Lal.
Post LPA, arbitrators entered reference; Mar 1, 1954 Agents claim: 1942 void, assurances led to continued supply; estoppel; Rs.27,48,515 or alt Rs.25,63,037 + interest.
Govt resisted: no assurances, profitable under 1942; claims not covered by cl.20.
Arbitrators framed issues; May 2, 1954 award: 1942 binding; awarded est/cont Rs.80,994 actual loss + mandi Rs.11,27,965; total Rs.13,03,676 + interest from 1949 + costs.
Award filed Jun 2, 1954 Commercial Sub Judge Delhi; Govt applied ss.30/33 Arbitration Act to set aside: invalid, misconduct, error on face.
Sub Judge: error on face but specific reference, binding; rejected set aside.
Govt appealed to Punjab HC Chandigarh; Agents supported on quantum meruit.
HC: no specific reference, errors on face, no legal basis; set aside award.
SC appeal with leave under Art.133(1)(a).

legal_issues.text: Whether the reference to arbitrators was specific or general, allowing challenge for error on face of award.
Whether supplementary agreement dated June 20, 1942 was valid and binding, or void due to war conditions.
Whether arbitrators could award additional establishment/contingencies and mandi/financing charges beyond stipulated rates, on quantum meruit or equity.
Whether Govt assurances estopped repudiation of claims.

petitioner_arguments.text: 1942 agreement not binding, entitled to original 1937 rates (Sch.A).
Alt: revise rates est/cont (Sch.B), mandi (Sch.C); damages termination (Sch.D).
1942 void due to war change in circumstances; assurances by Chief Director led to continued supply; estoppel.
Specific reference or claims within cl.20; previous decisions bar res judicata on jurisdiction.
War frustrated contract or justify ignoring terms for equity/quantum meruit.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.56 Indian Contract Act; British Movietonews

respondent_arguments.text: No revision during currency; only ex-gratia if loss proved.
1942 agreement binding by mutual consent post-war start; supplies profitable thereunder.
No assurances; claims not covered by cl.20, no jurisdiction.
General reference, error on face: ignored express terms for est/cont (cl.14,12b), mandi (cl.13a,12b).

court_reasoning.text: Reference was general, not specific question of law; award challengeable for error on face.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Letters show general reference under cl.20; issues to focus disputes.

court_reasoning.text: 1942 supplementary agreement valid and binding; made post-war by mutual consent.
Arbitrators erred on face by awarding extra beyond express rates for est/cont and mandi; no authority to ignore covenants.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contract stipulates rates; paid as per; no frustration.

court_reasoning.text: No estoppel by vague assurances; quantum meruit inapplicable where contract fixes price.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Compensation under contract terms only; s.222 not for excess.

court_reasoning.text: No frustration under s.56; performance not impossible; no general equity to vary terms on changed circumstances.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts cannot absolve on onerous performance; true construction.

court_reasoning.text: No res judicata on jurisdiction from prior proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prior set aside on misconduct; no binding decision on Sch.B/C.

holdings.text: Reference general; award set aside for errors on face: ignored express contract rates.
1942 agreement binding; no extra payment on quantum meruit or equity.
s.56 not applicable; no frustration or variation by circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Champsey Bhara and Company v. Jivaraj Balloo Spinning and Weaving Company, Limited
precedents_cited.relevance: Error on face only if legal proposition basis of award erroneous.
Specific question answered binds even if erroneous.

precedents_cited.case_name: Government of Kelantan v. Duff Development Company Limited
British Movietonews Ltd. v. London and District Cinemas Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: No general liberty to vary contract on changed circumstances; Denning LJ views negatived.

precedents_cited.case_name: Constantines case (Olley v. Marlborough Court Ltd.? inferred)
Hirji Mulji v. Cheong Yue Steamship Co. Ltd.
Parkinson & Co. Ltd. v. Commissioners of Works
precedents_cited.relevance: Implied term on true interpretation, not general equity.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: No frustration as performance not impossible; no indemnity beyond stipulated for excess charges.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Arbitration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Grounds to set aside award: error on face in general reference.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, affirmed High Court order setting aside the arbitrators' award, holding it erroneous on face for awarding amounts beyond express contract rates in general reference; no basis in quantum meruit, equity, or frustration.

key_quotes.text: The award of an arbitrator may be set aside on the ground of an error on the face thereof only when in the award or in any document incorporated with it... there is found some legal proposition which is the basis of the award and which is erroneous.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of court interference with arbitral award.

key_quotes.text: A contract is not frustrated merely because the circumstances in which the contract was made, are altered.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects claim to vary terms due to war conditions.

key_quotes.text: Compensation quantum meruit is awarded for work done or services rendered, when the price thereof is not fixed by a contract.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains inapplicability where contract stipulates rates.
